The Beginning of Epistemology: From Homer to Philolaus’, 11–38, for a good introduction to epistemology in the period. On Xenophanes’ epistemology see James Lesher’s Xenophanes of Colophon. Fragments: A Text and Translation with a Commentary

Geach claimed that it was a fallacy to maintain that knowledge of a Form was prior to the recognition of its putative instances. See also along these lines Russell Dancy, Plato’s Introduction of Forms
note: An older book with which I disagree though from which I have learned a great deal is by Jon Moline, Plato’s Theory of Understanding
title: Mi-Kyoung Lee’s Epistemology After Protagoras. Responses to Relativism in Plato, Aristotle, and Democritus

is an excellent treatment of epistemological issues uniting Presocratics and their successors. For analyses of Protagoras’ argument that ‘man is the measure of all things’ see Myles Burnyeat’s ‘Protagoras and Self-refutation in Later Greek Philosophy’
Relativism and Self-Refutation: Plato, Protagoras, and Burnyeat’
Of the enormous literature on Parmenides, for a good discussion of the epistemological implications of his argument see Patricia Curd, The Legacy of Parmenides
reprinted with a new introduction
Mention here should be made of a topic not dealt with in this book, but well treated by Voula Tsouna in The Epistemology of the Cyrenaic School

on the Socratic school which offered a form of scepticism flowing from their ethical hedonism. Chapter 3. Most of the countless books on Plato’s philosophy touch at least in part on his epistemology or various aspects of it. On the epistemological origins of Platonic epistemology in the so-called Socratic elenchus, see an influential paper by Peter Geach, ‘Plato’s Euthyphro: An Analysis and Commentary
The Socratic Fallacy and the Epistemological Priority of Definitional Knowledge’

container-title: ‘Knowledge and Belief in Republic V–VII’, in Everson, Companions to Ancient Thought I, 85–115, in ‘Knowledge and True Belief in the Meno’, Oxford Studies in Ancient Philosophy
title: Another recent work of note is by Dominic Scott, Recollection and Experience. Plato’s Theory of Learning and its Successors
I have discussed at length the position developed in this book in Lloyd Gerson, Knowing Persons. A Study in Plato
especially chs. 4 168 Further reading and 5. Gail Fine, ‘Knowledge and Belief in Plato’s Republic V’

Aristotle on Science: The Posterior Analytics. Proceedings of the Eighth Symposium Aristotelicum
note: contains a number of superb papers, many of which focus on knowledge in that work. Of special note is Myles Burnyeat’s ‘Aristotle on Understanding Knowledge,’ 97–139.
title: Myths About Non-Propositional Thought’

for an influential argument against one position taken in the present work. On mathematical developments within Plato’s philosophy two books by Kenneth Sayre are particularly helpful: Plato’s Later Ontology. A Riddle Resolved (Princeton University Press, 1983); and Metaphysics and Method in Plato’s Statesman

is where the ‘myth of the given’ is first discussed and criticised. Chapter 4. A collection of papers on Aristotle’s Posterior Analytics by

container-title: Michael Wedin in his Mind and Imagination in Aristotle
note: There are in volume I helpful chapters on Epicurean, Stoic and sceptical epistemology. Another major resource is Keimpe Algra, Jonathan Barnes, Jaap Mansfeld and Malcolm Schofield (eds.), The Cambridge History of Hellenistic Philosophy (Cambridge University Press, 1999). This volume contains substantial essays on Epicurean, Stoic and Academic epistemology. Also see Malcolm Schofield, Myles Burnyeat and Jonathan Barnes (eds.), Doubt and Dogmatism.
title: acutely argues for what I take to be a reductivist position about knowledge in Aristotle, one which would set him sharply apart from Plato
for a good collection of essays both on epistemological matters and on other psychological issues in that work
Aristotle’s Metaphysics

especially chs. 2 and 3, contains a good discussion of Aristotelian epistemology generally. For a recent nuanced defence of the view that the intellect in De Anima chapter five is in fact identical with the Unmoved Mover, see Victor Caston, ‘Aristotle’s Two Intellects: A Modest Proposal’
Chapter 5. In recent years there has been a remarkable increase in scholarship on the material dealt with in this chapter and the next. The best place to begin is with A

note: Chapter 6. Not surprisingly, ancient scepticism – as found in the Academy and in its Pyrrhonist versions – is the topic in ancient epistemology that resonates most frequently with contemporary philosophers. In addition to the collections mentioned above, see Richard Bett, Pyrrho. His Antecedents and his Legacy (Oxford University Press, 2000); Myles Burnyeat (ed.), The Skeptical Tradition (Berkeley/
title: Studies in Hellenistic Epistemology
Also see Gisela Striker’s Essays on Hellenistic Epistemology and Ethics
A useful study on a crucial topic in Hellenistic epistemology is James Allen’s Inference From Signs
On Epicurean epistemology in particular see Stephen Everson’s ‘Epicurus on the Truth of the Senses’

title: The Skeptic Way
which has a substantial philosophical introduction to a translation of Sextus’ Outlines of Pyrrhonism; Alan Bailey, Sextus Empiricus and Pyrrhonean Scepticism

title: Plato the Sceptic’, in Oxford Studies in Ancient Philosophy, supp

which takes up the question of the justification for the Academic claim that scepticism is in harmony with Plato’s teaching. On later Academics see Richard Bett, ‘Carneades’ Pithanon: A Reappraisal of its Role and Status’
The Last of the Academic Sceptics

note: 250–74, which takes up the theme of selfconsciousness in Plotinus’ epistemology. Of some value is H. Oosthout’s Modes of Knowledge and the Transcendental: An Introduction to Plotinus Ennead 5.3
title: with an extensive and useful introduction treating of the Academic–Stoic debates. Chapter 8. Plotinus’ epistemology is not easily treated apart from his larger philosophical position, especially his metaphysics. An essay by Eyjólfur Emilsson, ‘Cognition and its Objects’
is a good place to start. Also see his Plotinus on Sense-Perception: A Philosophical Study
Also in The Cambridge Companion is Sara Rappe’s ‘Self-Knowledge and Subjectivity in the Enneads’
A wider-ranging book on various facets of Plotinus’ epistemology is Gary Gertler’s Plotinus

title: Hilary Kornblith edited a collection Naturalizing Epistemology
that includes seminal essays on the pros and cons of naturalism. His book Knowledge and its Place in Nature
elaborates on earlier work. An influential argument against naturalism in epistemology is by Jaegwon Kim, ‘What is “Naturalized Epistemology?”’
